title: CycloneDX Bill of Materials Standard
$comment: CycloneDX JSON schema is published under the terms of the Apache License 2.0.

bomFormat.title: BOM Format
bomFormat.description: Specifies the format of the BOM. This helps to identify the file as CycloneDX since BOMs do not have a filename convention, nor does JSON schema support namespaces. This value MUST be "CycloneDX".

specVersion.title: CycloneDX Specification Version
specVersion.description: The version of the CycloneDX specification the BOM conforms to.

serialNumber.title: BOM Serial Number
serialNumber.description: Every BOM generated SHOULD have a unique serial number, even if the contents of the BOM have not changed over time. If specified, the serial number MUST conform to RFC-4122. Use of serial numbers is RECOMMENDED.

version.title: BOM Version
version.description: Whenever an existing BOM is modified, either manually or through automated processes, the version of the BOM SHOULD be incremented by 1. When a system is presented with multiple BOMs with identical serial numbers, the system SHOULD use the most recent version of the BOM. The default version is '1'.

metadata.title: BOM Metadata
metadata.description: Provides additional information about a BOM.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of software and hardware components.

services.title: Services
services.description: A list of services. This may include microservices, function-as-a-service, and other types of network or intra-process services.

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

dependencies.title: Dependencies
dependencies.description: Provides the ability to document dependency relationships including provided & implemented components.

compositions.title: Compositions
compositions.description: Compositions describe constituent parts (including components, services, and dependency relationships) and their completeness. The completeness of vulnerabilities expressed in a BOM may also be described.

vulnerabilities.title: Vulnerabilities
vulnerabilities.description: Vulnerabilities identified in components or services.

annotations.title: Annotations
annotations.description: Comments made by people, organizations, or tools about any object with a bom-ref, such as components, services, vulnerabilities, or the BOM itself. Unlike inventory information, annotations may contain opinions or commentary from various stakeholders. Annotations may be inline (with inventory) or externalized via BOM-Link and may optionally be signed.

formulation.title: Formulation
formulation.description: Describes how a component or service was manufactured or deployed. This is achieved through the use of formulas, workflows, tasks, and steps, which declare the precise steps to reproduce along with the observed formulas describing the steps which transpired in the manufacturing process.

declarations.title: Declarations
declarations.description: The list of declarations which describe the conformance to standards. Each declaration may include attestations, claims, and evidence.

assessors.title: Assessors
assessors.description: The list of assessors evaluating claims and determining conformance to requirements and confidence in that assessment.

items.title: Assessor
items.description: The assessor who evaluates claims and determines conformance to requirements and confidence in that assessment.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description: An optional identifier which can be used to reference the object elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.

thirdParty.title: Third Party
thirdParty.description: The boolean indicating if the assessor is outside the organization generating claims. A value of false indicates a self assessor.

attestations.title: Attestations
attestations.description: The list of attestations asserted by an assessor that maps requirements to claims.

summary.title: Summary
summary.description: The short description explaining the main points of the attestation.

assessor.title: Assessor
assessor.description: The `bom-ref` to the assessor asserting the attestation.

map.title: Map
map.description: The grouping of requirements to claims and the attestors declared conformance and confidence thereof.

requirement.title: Requirement
requirement.description: The `bom-ref` to the requirement being attested to.

claims.title: Claims
claims.description: The list of `bom-ref` to the claims being attested to.

counterClaims.title: Counter Claims
counterClaims.description: The list of  `bom-ref` to the counter claims being attested to.

conformance.title: Conformance
conformance.description: The conformance of the claim meeting a requirement.

score.title: Score
score.description: The conformance of the claim between and inclusive of 0 and 1, where 1 is 100% conformance.

rationale.title: Rationale
rationale.description: The rationale for the conformance score.

mitigationStrategies.title: Mitigation Strategies
mitigationStrategies.description: The list of  `bom-ref` to the evidence provided describing the mitigation strategies.

confidence.title: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence of the claim meeting the requirement.

score.title: Score
score.description: The confidence of the claim between and inclusive of 0 and 1, where 1 is 100% confidence.

rationale.title: Rationale
rationale.description: The rationale for the confidence score.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description: An optional identifier which can be used to reference the object elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.

target.title: Target
target.description: The `bom-ref` to a target representing a specific system, application, API, module, team, person, process, business unit, company, etc...  that this claim is being applied to.

predicate.title: Predicate
predicate.description: The specific statement or assertion about the target.

mitigationStrategies.title: Mitigation Strategies
mitigationStrategies.description: The list of  `bom-ref` to the evidence provided describing the mitigation strategies. Each mitigation strategy should include an explanation of how any weaknesses in the evidence will be mitigated.

reasoning.title: Reasoning
reasoning.description: The written explanation of why the evidence provided substantiates the claim.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: The list of `bom-ref` to evidence that supports this claim.

counterEvidence.title: Counter Evidence
counterEvidence.description: The list of `bom-ref` to counterEvidence that supports this claim.

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description: An optional identifier which can be used to reference the object elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.

propertyName.title: Property Name
propertyName.description: The reference to the property name as defined in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy/).

description.title: Description
description.description: The written description of what this evidence is and how it was created.

data.title: Data
data.description: The output or analysis that supports claims.

name.title: Data Name
name.description: The name of the data.

contents.title: Data Contents
contents.description: The contents or references to the contents of the data being described.

attachment.title: Data Attachment
attachment.description: An optional way to include textual or encoded data.

url.title: Data URL
url.description: The URL to where the data can be retrieved.

sensitiveData.title: Sensitive Data
sensitiveData.description: A description of any sensitive data included.

created.title: Created
created.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the evidence was created.

expires.title: Expires
expires.description: The optional date and time (timestamp) when the evidence is no longer valid.

targets.title: Targets
targets.description: The list of targets which claims are made against.

organizations.title: Organizations
organizations.description: The list of organizations which claims are made against.

components.title: Components
components.description: The list of components which claims are made against.

services.title: Services
services.description: The list of services which claims are made against.

statement.title: Statement
statement.description:
The brief statement affirmed by an individual regarding all declarations.
*- Notes This could be an affirmation of acceptance by a third-party auditor or receiving individual of a file.
examples: I certify, to the best of my knowledge, that all information is correct.

signatories.title: Signatories
signatories.description: The list of signatories authorized on behalf of an organization to assert validity of this document.

name.title: Name
name.description: The signatory's name.

role.title: Role
role.description: The signatory's role within an organization.

externalReference.title: External Reference
externalReference.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

definitions.title: Definitions
definitions.description: A collection of reusable objects that are defined and may be used elsewhere in the BOM.

standards.title: Standards
standards.description: The list of standards which may consist of regulations, industry or organizational-specific standards, maturity models, best practices, or any other requirements which can be evaluated against or attested to.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

refType.description:
Identifier for referable and therefore interlinkable elements.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.
refType.$comment: TODO (breaking change): add a format constraint that prevents the value from staring with 'urn:cdx:'

refLinkType.description:
Descriptor for an element identified by the attribute 'bom-ref' in the same BOM document.
In contrast to `bomLinkElementType`.

bomLinkDocumentType.title: BOM-Link Document
bomLinkDocumentType.description: Descriptor for another BOM document. See https://cyclonedx.org/capabilities/bomlink/
bomLinkDocumentType.$comment: part of the pattern is based on `bom.serialNumber`'s pattern

bomLinkElementType.title: BOM-Link Element
bomLinkElementType.description: Descriptor for an element in a BOM document. See https://cyclonedx.org/capabilities/bomlink/
bomLinkElementType.$comment: part of the pattern is based on `bom.serialNumber`'s pattern

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the BOM was created.

lifecycles.title: Lifecycles
lifecycles.description: Lifecycles communicate the stage(s) in which data in the BOM was captured. Different types of data may be available at various phases of a lifecycle, such as the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC), IT Asset Management (ITAM), and Software Asset Management (SAM). Thus, a BOM may include data specific to or only obtainable in a given lifecycle.

items.title: Lifecycle
items.description: The product lifecycle(s) that this BOM represents.

phase.title: Phase
phase.description: A pre-defined phase in the product lifecycle.

meta:enum.design: BOM produced early in the development lifecycle containing an inventory of components and services that are proposed or planned to be used. The inventory may need to be procured, retrieved, or resourced prior to use.
meta:enum.pre-build: BOM consisting of information obtained prior to a build process and may contain source files and development artifacts and manifests. The inventory may need to be resolved and retrieved prior to use.
meta:enum.build: BOM consisting of information obtained during a build process where component inventory is available for use. The precise versions of resolved components are usually available at this time as well as the provenance of where the components were retrieved from.
meta:enum.post-build: BOM consisting of information obtained after a build process has completed and the resulting components(s) are available for further analysis. Built components may exist as the result of a CI/CD process, may have been installed or deployed to a system or device, and may need to be retrieved or extracted from the system or device.
meta:enum.operations: BOM produced that represents inventory that is running and operational. This may include staging or production environments and will generally encompass multiple SBOMs describing the applications and operating system, along with HBOMs describing the hardware that makes up the system. Operations Bill of Materials (OBOM) can provide full-stack inventory of runtime environments, configurations, and additional dependencies.
meta:enum.discovery: BOM consisting of information observed through network discovery providing point-in-time enumeration of embedded, on-premise, and cloud-native services such as server applications, connected devices, microservices, and serverless functions.
meta:enum.decommission: BOM containing inventory that will be, or has been retired from operations.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the lifecycle phase

description.title: Description
description.description: The description of the lifecycle phase

tools.title: Tools
tools.description: The tool(s) used in the creation, enrichment, and validation of the BOM.

oneOf.title: Tools
oneOf.description: The tool(s) used in the creation, enrichment, and validation of the BOM.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of software and hardware components used as tools.

services.title: Services
services.description: A list of services used as tools. This may include microservices, function-as-a-service, and other types of network or intra-process services.

oneOf.title: Tools (legacy)
oneOf.description: [Deprecated] The tool(s) used in the creation, enrichment, and validation of the BOM.

manufacturer.title: BOM Manufacturer
manufacturer.description:
The organization that created the BOM.
Manufacturer is common in BOMs created through automated processes. BOMs created through manual means may have `@.authors` instead.

authors.title: BOM Authors
authors.description:
The person(s) who created the BOM.
Authors are common in BOMs created through manual processes. BOMs created through automated means may have `@.manufacturer` instead.

component.title: Component
component.description: The component that the BOM describes.

manufacture.title: Component Manufacture (legacy)
manufacture.description:
[Deprecated] This will be removed in a future version. Use the `@.component.manufacturer` instead.
The organization that manufactured the component that the BOM describes.

supplier.title: Supplier
supplier.description: The organization that supplied the component that the BOM describes. The supplier may often be the manufacturer, but may also be a distributor or repackager.

licenses.title: BOM License(s)
licenses.description:
The license information for the BOM document.
This may be different from the license(s) of the component(s) that the BOM describes.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

tool.title: Tool
tool.description: [Deprecated] This will be removed in a future version. Use component or service instead. Information about the automated or manual tool used

vendor.title: Tool Vendor
vendor.description: The name of the vendor who created the tool

name.title: Tool Name
name.description: The name of the tool

hashes.title: Hashes
hashes.description: The hashes of the tool (if applicable).

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant, but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the object elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

name.title: Organization Name
name.description: The name of the organization

address.title: Organization Address
address.description: The physical address (location) of the organization

url.title: Organization URL(s)
url.description: The URL of the organization. Multiple URLs are allowed.

contact.title: Organizational Contact
contact.description: A contact at the organization. Multiple contacts are allowed.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the object elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of a contact

email.title: Email Address
email.description: The email address of the contact.

phone.title: Phone
phone.description: The phone number of the contact.

meta:enum.application: A software application. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_software) for information about applications.
meta:enum.framework: A software framework. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_framework](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_framework) for information on how frameworks vary slightly from libraries.
meta:enum.library: A software library. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Library_(computing)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Library_(computing)) for information about libraries. All third-party and open source reusable components will likely be a library. If the library also has key features of a framework, then it should be classified as a framework. If not, or is unknown, then specifying library is RECOMMENDED.
meta:enum.container: A packaging and/or runtime format, not specific to any particular technology, which isolates software inside the container from software outside of a container through virtualization technology. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS-level_virtualization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS-level_virtualization).
meta:enum.platform: A runtime environment which interprets or executes software. This may include runtimes such as those that execute bytecode or low-code/no-code application platforms.
meta:enum.operating-system: A software operating system without regard to deployment model (i.e. installed on physical hardware, virtual machine, image, etc) Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system).
meta:enum.device: A hardware device such as a processor or chip-set. A hardware device containing firmware SHOULD include a component for the physical hardware itself and another component of type 'firmware' or 'operating-system' (whichever is relevant), describing information about the software running on the device. See also the list of [known device properties](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy/blob/main/cdx/device.md).
meta:enum.device-driver: A special type of software that operates or controls a particular type of device. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver).
meta:enum.firmware: A special type of software that provides low-level control over a device's hardware. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firmware](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firmware).
meta:enum.file: A computer file. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file) for information about files.
meta:enum.machine-learning-model: A model based on training data that can make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed to do so.
meta:enum.data: A collection of discrete values that convey information.
meta:enum.cryptographic-asset: A cryptographic asset including algorithms, protocols, certificates, keys, tokens, and secrets.

type.title: Component Type
type.description: Specifies the type of component. For software components, classify as application if no more specific appropriate classification is available or cannot be determined for the component.

mime-type.title: Mime-Type
mime-type.description: The optional mime-type of the component. When used on file components, the mime-type can provide additional context about the kind of file being represented, such as an image, font, or executable. Some library or framework components may also have an associated mime-type.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the component elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

supplier.title: Component Supplier
supplier.description: The organization that supplied the component. The supplier may often be the manufacturer, but may also be a distributor or repackager.

manufacturer.title: Component Manufacturer
manufacturer.description:
The organization that created the component.
Manufacturer is common in components created through automated processes. Components created through manual means may have `@.authors` instead.

authors.title: Component Authors
authors.description:
The person(s) who created the component.
Authors are common in components created through manual processes. Components created through automated means may have `@.manufacturer` instead.

author.title: Component Author (legacy)
author.description:
[Deprecated] This will be removed in a future version. Use `@.authors` or `@.manufacturer` instead.
The person(s) or organization(s) that authored the component

publisher.title: Component Publisher
publisher.description: The person(s) or organization(s) that published the component

group.title: Component Group
group.description: The grouping name or identifier. This will often be a shortened, single name of the company or project that produced the component, or the source package or domain name. Whitespace and special characters should be avoided. Examples include: apache, org.apache.commons, and apache.org.

name.title: Component Name
name.description: The name of the component. This will often be a shortened, single name of the component. Examples: commons-lang3 and jquery

version.title: Component Version
version.description: The component version. The version should ideally comply with semantic versioning but is not enforced.

description.title: Component Description
description.description: Specifies a description for the component

meta:enum.required: The component is required for runtime
meta:enum.optional: The component is optional at runtime. Optional components are components that are not capable of being called due to them not being installed or otherwise accessible by any means. Components that are installed but due to configuration or other restrictions are prohibited from being called must be scoped as 'required'.
meta:enum.excluded: Components that are excluded provide the ability to document component usage for test and other non-runtime purposes. Excluded components are not reachable within a call graph at runtime.

scope.title: Component Scope
scope.description: Specifies the scope of the component. If scope is not specified, 'required' scope SHOULD be assumed by the consumer of the BOM.

copyright.title: Component Copyright
copyright.description: A copyright notice informing users of the underlying claims to copyright ownership in a published work.

cpe.title: Common Platform Enumeration (CPE)
cpe.description: Asserts the identity of the component using CPE. The CPE must conform to the CPE 2.2 or 2.3 specification. See [https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe](https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

purl.title: Package URL (purl)
purl.description: Asserts the identity of the component using package-url (purl). The purl, if specified, MUST be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec](https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

omniborId.title: OmniBOR Artifact Identifier (gitoid)
omniborId.description: Asserts the identity of the component using the OmniBOR Artifact ID. The OmniBOR, if specified, MUST be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/prov/gitoid](https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/prov/gitoid). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

swhid.title: SoftWare Heritage Identifier
swhid.description: Asserts the identity of the component using the Software Heritage persistent identifier (SWHID). The SWHID, if specified, MUST be valid and conform to the specification defined at: [https://docs.softwareheritage.org/devel/swh-model/persistent-identifiers.html](https://docs.softwareheritage.org/devel/swh-model/persistent-identifiers.html). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

swid.title: SWID Tag
swid.description: Asserts the identity of the component using [ISO-IEC 19770-2 Software Identification (SWID) Tags](https://www.iso.org/standard/65666.html). Refer to `@.evidence.identity` to optionally provide evidence that substantiates the assertion of the component's identity.

modified.title: Component Modified From Original
modified.description: [Deprecated] This will be removed in a future version. Use the pedigree element instead to supply information on exactly how the component was modified. A boolean value indicating if the component has been modified from the original. A value of true indicates the component is a derivative of the original. A value of false indicates the component has not been modified from the original.

pedigree.title: Component Pedigree
pedigree.description: Component pedigree is a way to document complex supply chain scenarios where components are created, distributed, modified, redistributed, combined with other components, etc. Pedigree supports viewing this complex chain from the beginning, the end, or anywhere in the middle. It also provides a way to document variants where the exact relation may not be known.

ancestors.title: Ancestors
ancestors.description: Describes zero or more components in which a component is derived from. This is commonly used to describe forks from existing projects where the forked version contains a ancestor node containing the original component it was forked from. For example, Component A is the original component. Component B is the component being used and documented in the BOM. However, Component B contains a pedigree node with a single ancestor documenting Component A - the original component from which Component B is derived from.

descendants.title: Descendants
descendants.description: Descendants are the exact opposite of ancestors. This provides a way to document all forks (and their forks) of an original or root component.

variants.title: Variants
variants.description: Variants describe relations where the relationship between the components is not known. For example, if Component A contains nearly identical code to Component B. They are both related, but it is unclear if one is derived from the other, or if they share a common ancestor.

commits.title: Commits
commits.description: A list of zero or more commits which provide a trail describing how the component deviates from an ancestor, descendant, or variant.

patches.title: Patches
patches.description: >A list of zero or more patches describing how the component deviates from an ancestor, descendant, or variant. Patches may be complementary to commits or may be used in place of commits.

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: Notes, observations, and other non-structured commentary describing the components pedigree.

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of software and hardware components included in the parent component. This is not a dependency tree. It provides a way to specify a hierarchical representation of component assemblies, similar to system → subsystem → parts assembly in physical supply chains.

evidence.title: Evidence
evidence.description: Provides the ability to document evidence collected through various forms of extraction or analysis.

data.title: Data
data.description: This object SHOULD be specified for any component of type `data` and MUST NOT be specified for other component types.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

swid.title: SWID Tag
swid.description: Specifies metadata and content for ISO-IEC 19770-2 Software Identification (SWID) Tags.

tagId.title: Tag ID
tagId.description: Maps to the tagId of a SoftwareIdentity.

name.title: Name
name.description: Maps to the name of a SoftwareIdentity.

version.title: Version
version.description: Maps to the version of a SoftwareIdentity.

tagVersion.title: Tag Version
tagVersion.description: Maps to the tagVersion of a SoftwareIdentity.

patch.title: Patch
patch.description: Maps to the patch of a SoftwareIdentity.

text.title: Attachment text
text.description: Specifies the metadata and content of the SWID tag.

url.title: URL
url.description: The URL to the SWID file.

attachment.title: Attachment
attachment.description: Specifies the metadata and content for an attachment.

contentType.title: Content-Type
contentType.description: Specifies the content type of the text. Defaults to text/plain if not specified.

encoding.title: Encoding
encoding.description: Specifies the optional encoding the text is represented in.

meta:enum.base64: Base64 is a binary-to-text encoding scheme that represents binary data in an ASCII string.

content.title: Attachment Text
content.description: The attachment data. Proactive controls such as input validation and sanitization should be employed to prevent misuse of attachment text.

hash-alg.title: Hash Algorithm
hash-alg.description: The algorithm that generated the hash value.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the license elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

name.title: License Name
name.description: If SPDX does not define the license used, this field may be used to provide the license name

text.title: License text
text.description: An optional way to include the textual content of a license.

url.title: License URL
url.description: The URL to the license file. If specified, a 'license' externalReference should also be specified for completeness

licensing.title: Licensing information
licensing.description: Licensing details describing the licensor/licensee, license type, renewal and expiration dates, and other important metadata

altIds.title: Alternate License Identifiers
altIds.description: License identifiers that may be used to manage licenses and their lifecycle

licensor.title: Licensor
licensor.description: The individual or organization that grants a license to another individual or organization

organization.title: Licensor (Organization)
organization.description: The organization that granted the license

individual.title: Licensor (Individual)
individual.description: The individual, not associated with an organization, that granted the license

licensee.title: Licensee
licensee.description: The individual or organization for which a license was granted to

organization.title: Licensee (Organization)
organization.description: The organization that was granted the license

individual.title: Licensee (Individual)
individual.description: The individual, not associated with an organization, that was granted the license

purchaser.title: Purchaser
purchaser.description: The individual or organization that purchased the license

organization.title: Purchaser (Organization)
organization.description: The organization that purchased the license

individual.title: Purchaser (Individual)
individual.description: The individual, not associated with an organization, that purchased the license

purchaseOrder.title: Purchase Order
purchaseOrder.description: The purchase order identifier the purchaser sent to a supplier or vendor to authorize a purchase

licenseTypes.title: License Type
licenseTypes.description: The type of license(s) that was granted to the licensee.

meta:enum.academic: A license that grants use of software solely for the purpose of education or research.
meta:enum.appliance: A license covering use of software embedded in a specific piece of hardware.
meta:enum.client-access: A Client Access License (CAL) allows client computers to access services provided by server software.
meta:enum.concurrent-user: A Concurrent User license (aka floating license) limits the number of licenses for a software application and licenses are shared among a larger number of users.
meta:enum.core-points: A license where the core of a computer's processor is assigned a specific number of points.
meta:enum.custom-metric: A license for which consumption is measured by non-standard metrics.
meta:enum.device: A license that covers a defined number of installations on computers and other types of devices.
meta:enum.evaluation: A license that grants permission to install and use software for trial purposes.
meta:enum.named-user: A license that grants access to the software to one or more pre-defined users.
meta:enum.node-locked: A license that grants access to the software on one or more pre-defined computers or devices.
meta:enum.oem: An Original Equipment Manufacturer license that is delivered with hardware, cannot be transferred to other hardware, and is valid for the life of the hardware.
meta:enum.perpetual: A license where the software is sold on a one-time basis and the licensee can use a copy of the software indefinitely.
meta:enum.processor-points: A license where each installation consumes points per processor.
meta:enum.subscription: A license where the licensee pays a fee to use the software or service.
meta:enum.user: A license that grants access to the software or service by a specified number of users.

lastRenewal.title: Last Renewal
lastRenewal.description: The timestamp indicating when the license was last renewed. For new purchases, this is often the purchase or acquisition date. For non-perpetual licenses or subscriptions, this is the timestamp of when the license was last renewed.

expiration.title: Expiration
expiration.description: The timestamp indicating when the current license expires (if applicable).

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

licenseAcknowledgementEnumeration.title: License Acknowledgement
licenseAcknowledgementEnumeration.description: Declared licenses and concluded licenses represent two different stages in the licensing process within software development. Declared licenses refer to the initial intention of the software authors regarding the licensing terms under which their code is released. On the other hand, concluded licenses are the result of a comprehensive analysis of the project's codebase to identify and confirm the actual licenses of the components used, which may differ from the initially declared licenses. While declared licenses provide an upfront indication of the licensing intentions, concluded licenses offer a more thorough understanding of the actual licensing within a project, facilitating proper compliance and risk management. Observed licenses are defined in `@.evidence.licenses`. Observed licenses form the evidence necessary to substantiate a concluded license.

meta:enum.declared: Declared licenses represent the initial intentions of authors regarding the licensing terms of their code.
meta:enum.concluded: Concluded licenses are verified and confirmed.

licenseChoice.title: License Choice
licenseChoice.description: EITHER (list of SPDX licenses and/or named licenses) OR (tuple of one SPDX License Expression)

oneOf.title: Multiple licenses
oneOf.description: A list of SPDX licenses and/or named licenses.

oneOf.title: SPDX License Expression
oneOf.description: A tuple of exactly one SPDX License Expression.

expression.title: SPDX License Expression
expression.description:
A valid SPDX license expression.
Refer to https://spdx.org/specifications for syntax requirements

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the license elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

uid.title: UID
uid.description: A unique identifier of the commit. This may be version control specific. For example, Subversion uses revision numbers whereas git uses commit hashes.

url.title: URL
url.description: The URL to the commit. This URL will typically point to a commit in a version control system.

author.title: Author
author.description: The author who created the changes in the commit

committer.title: Committer
committer.description: The person who committed or pushed the commit

message.title: Message
message.description: The text description of the contents of the commit

meta:enum.unofficial: A patch which is not developed by the creators or maintainers of the software being patched. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unofficial_patch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unofficial_patch).
meta:enum.monkey: A patch which dynamically modifies runtime behavior. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monkey_patch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monkey_patch).
meta:enum.backport: A patch which takes code from a newer version of the software and applies it to older versions of the same software. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backporting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backporting).
meta:enum.cherry-pick: A patch created by selectively applying commits from other versions or branches of the same software.

type.title: Patch Type
type.description: Specifies the purpose for the patch including the resolution of defects, security issues, or new behavior or functionality.

diff.title: Diff
diff.description: The patch file (or diff) that shows changes. Refer to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diff)

resolves.title: Resolves
resolves.description: A collection of issues the patch resolves

diff.title: Diff
diff.description: The patch file (or diff) that shows changes. Refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diff

text.title: Diff text
text.description: Specifies the optional text of the diff

url.title: URL
url.description: Specifies the URL to the diff

issue.title: Issue
issue.description: An individual issue that has been resolved.

meta:enum.defect: A fault, flaw, or bug in software.
meta:enum.enhancement: A new feature or behavior in software.
meta:enum.security: A special type of defect which impacts security.

id.title: Issue ID
id.description: The identifier of the issue assigned by the source of the issue

name.title: Issue Name
name.description: The name of the issue

description.title: Issue Description
description.description: A description of the issue

source.title: Source
source.description: The source of the issue where it is documented

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the source.

url.title: URL
url.description: The url of the issue documentation as provided by the source

references.title: References
references.description: A collection of URL's for reference. Multiple URLs are allowed.

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: The timestamp in which the action occurred

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the individual who performed the action

email.title: E-mail
email.description: The email address of the individual who performed the action

externalReference.title: External Reference
externalReference.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

url.title: URL
url.description: The URI (URL or URN) to the external reference. External references are URIs and therefore can accept any URL scheme including https ([RFC-7230](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc7230.txt)), mailto ([RFC-2368](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2368.txt)), tel ([RFC-3966](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3966.txt)), and dns ([RFC-4501](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4501.txt)). External references may also include formally registered URNs such as [CycloneDX BOM-Link](https://cyclonedx.org/capabilities/bomlink/) to reference CycloneDX BOMs or any object within a BOM. BOM-Link transforms applicable external references into relationships that can be expressed in a BOM or across BOMs.

comment.title: Comment
comment.description: An optional comment describing the external reference

type.title: Type
type.description: Specifies the type of external reference.

meta:enum.issue-tracker: Issue or defect tracking system, or an Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) system
meta:enum.bom: Bill of Materials (SBOM, OBOM, HBOM, SaaSBOM, etc)
meta:enum.source-distribution: The location where the source code distributable can be obtained. This is often an archive format such as zip or tgz. The source-distribution type complements use of the version control (vcs) type.
meta:enum.distribution-intake: The location where a component was published to. This is often the same as "distribution" but may also include specialized publishing processes that act as an intermediary.
meta:enum.license: The reference to the license file. If a license URL has been defined in the license node, it should also be defined as an external reference for completeness.
meta:enum.build-meta: Build-system specific meta file (i.e. pom.xml, package.json, .nuspec, etc)
meta:enum.build-system: Reference to an automated build system
meta:enum.security-contact: Specifies a way to contact the maintainer, supplier, or provider in the event of a security incident. Common URIs include links to a disclosure procedure, a mailto (RFC-2368) that specifies an email address, a tel (RFC-3966) that specifies a phone number, or dns (RFC-4501) that specifies the records containing DNS Security TXT.
meta:enum.model-card: A model card describes the intended uses of a machine learning model, potential limitations, biases, ethical considerations, training parameters, datasets used to train the model, performance metrics, and other relevant data useful for ML transparency.
meta:enum.log: A record of events that occurred in a computer system or application, such as problems, errors, or information on current operations.
meta:enum.configuration: Parameters or settings that may be used by other components or services.
meta:enum.evidence: Information used to substantiate a claim.
meta:enum.formulation: Describes how a component or service was manufactured or deployed.
meta:enum.attestation: Human or machine-readable statements containing facts, evidence, or testimony.
meta:enum.threat-model: An enumeration of identified weaknesses, threats, and countermeasures, dataflow diagram (DFD), attack tree, and other supporting documentation in human-readable or machine-readable format.
meta:enum.adversary-model: The defined assumptions, goals, and capabilities of an adversary.
meta:enum.risk-assessment: Identifies and analyzes the potential of future events that may negatively impact individuals, assets, and/or the environment. Risk assessments may also include judgments on the tolerability of each risk.
meta:enum.vulnerability-assertion: A Vulnerability Disclosure Report (VDR) which asserts the known and previously unknown vulnerabilities that affect a component, service, or product including the analysis and findings describing the impact (or lack of impact) that the reported vulnerability has on a component, service, or product.
meta:enum.exploitability-statement: A Vulnerability Exploitability eXchange (VEX) which asserts the known vulnerabilities that do not affect a product, product family, or organization, and optionally the ones that do. The VEX should include the analysis and findings describing the impact (or lack of impact) that the reported vulnerability has on the product, product family, or organization.
meta:enum.pentest-report: Results from an authorized simulated cyberattack on a component or service, otherwise known as a penetration test.
meta:enum.static-analysis-report: SARIF or proprietary machine or human-readable report for which static analysis has identified code quality, security, and other potential issues with the source code.
meta:enum.dynamic-analysis-report: Dynamic analysis report that has identified issues such as vulnerabilities and misconfigurations.
meta:enum.runtime-analysis-report: Report generated by analyzing the call stack of a running application.
meta:enum.component-analysis-report: Report generated by Software Composition Analysis (SCA), container analysis, or other forms of component analysis.
meta:enum.maturity-report: Report containing a formal assessment of an organization, business unit, or team against a maturity model.
meta:enum.certification-report: Industry, regulatory, or other certification from an accredited (if applicable) certification body.
meta:enum.codified-infrastructure: Code or configuration that defines and provisions virtualized infrastructure, commonly referred to as Infrastructure as Code (IaC).
meta:enum.quality-metrics: Report or system in which quality metrics can be obtained.
meta:enum.poam: Plans of Action and Milestones (POAM) complement an "attestation" external reference. POAM is defined by NIST as a "document that identifies tasks needing to be accomplished. It details resources required to accomplish the elements of the plan, any milestones in meeting the tasks and scheduled completion dates for the milestones".
meta:enum.electronic-signature: An e-signature is commonly a scanned representation of a written signature or a stylized script of the person's name.
meta:enum.digital-signature: A signature that leverages cryptography, typically public/private key pairs, which provides strong authenticity verification.
meta:enum.rfc-9116: Document that complies with RFC-9116 (A File Format to Aid in Security Vulnerability Disclosure)
meta:enum.other: Use this if no other types accurately describe the purpose of the external reference.

hashes.title: Hashes
hashes.description: The hashes of the external reference (if applicable).

dependency.title: Dependency
dependency.description: Defines the direct dependencies of a component, service, or the components provided/implemented by a given component. Components or services that do not have their own dependencies MUST be declared as empty elements within the graph. Components or services that are not represented in the dependency graph MAY have unknown dependencies. It is RECOMMENDED that implementations assume this to be opaque and not an indicator of an object being dependency-free. It is RECOMMENDED to leverage compositions to indicate unknown dependency graphs.

ref.title: Reference
ref.description: References a component or service by its bom-ref attribute

dependsOn.title: Depends On
dependsOn.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services that are dependencies of this dependency object.

provides.title: Provides
provides.description:
The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services that define a given specification or standard, which are provided or implemented by this dependency object.
For example, a cryptographic library which implements a cryptographic algorithm. A component which implements another component does not imply that the implementation is in use.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the service elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

provider.title: Provider
provider.description: The organization that provides the service.

group.title: Service Group
group.description: The grouping name, namespace, or identifier. This will often be a shortened, single name of the company or project that produced the service or domain name. Whitespace and special characters should be avoided.

name.title: Service Name
name.description: The name of the service. This will often be a shortened, single name of the service.

description.title: Service Description
description.description: Specifies a description for the service

endpoints.title: Endpoints
endpoints.description: The endpoint URIs of the service. Multiple endpoints are allowed.

authenticated.title: Authentication Required
authenticated.description: A boolean value indicating if the service requires authentication. A value of true indicates the service requires authentication prior to use. A value of false indicates the service does not require authentication.

x-trust-boundary.title: Crosses Trust Boundary
x-trust-boundary.description: A boolean value indicating if use of the service crosses a trust zone or boundary. A value of true indicates that by using the service, a trust boundary is crossed. A value of false indicates that by using the service, a trust boundary is not crossed.

trustZone.title: Trust Zone
trustZone.description: The name of the trust zone the service resides in.

data.title: Data
data.description: Specifies information about the data including the directional flow of data and the data classification.

externalReferences.title: External References
externalReferences.description: External references provide a way to document systems, sites, and information that may be relevant but are not included with the BOM. They may also establish specific relationships within or external to the BOM.

services.title: Services
services.description: A list of services included or deployed behind the parent service. This is not a dependency tree. It provides a way to specify a hierarchical representation of service assemblies.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

flow.title: Directional Flow
flow.description: Specifies the flow direction of the data. Direction is relative to the service. Inbound flow states that data enters the service. Outbound flow states that data leaves the service. Bi-directional states that data flows both ways and unknown states that the direction is not known.

name.title: Name
name.description: Name for the defined data

description.title: Description
description.description: Short description of the data content and usage
examples: Credit card information being exchanged in between the web app and the database

source.title: Source
source.description: The URI, URL, or BOM-Link of the components or services the data came in from

destination.title: Destination
destination.description: The URI, URL, or BOM-Link of the components or services the data is sent to

meta:enum.bi-directional: Data flows in and out of the service.
meta:enum.unknown: The directional flow of data is not known.

dataFlowDirection.title: Data flow direction
dataFlowDirection.description: Specifies the flow direction of the data. Direction is relative to the service.

componentEvidence.title: Evidence
componentEvidence.description: Provides the ability to document evidence collected through various forms of extraction or analysis.

identity.title: Identity Evidence
identity.description: Evidence that substantiates the identity of a component. The identity may be an object or an array of identity objects. Support for specifying identity as a single object was introduced in CycloneDX v1.5. Arrays were introduced in v1.6. It is RECOMMENDED that all implementations use arrays, even if only one identity object is specified.

occurrences.title: Occurrences
occurrences.description: Evidence of individual instances of a component spread across multiple locations.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the occurrence elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

location.title: Location
location.description: The location or path to where the component was found.

line.title: Line Number
line.description: The line number where the component was found.

offset.title: Offset
offset.description: The offset where the component was found.

symbol.title: Symbol
symbol.description: The symbol name that was found associated with the component.

additionalContext.title: Additional Context
additionalContext.description: Any additional context of the detected component (e.g. a code snippet).

callstack.title: Call Stack
callstack.description: Evidence of the components use through the callstack.

frames.title: Frames
frames.description: Within a call stack, a frame is a discrete unit that encapsulates an execution context, including local variables, parameters, and the return address. As function calls are made, frames are pushed onto the stack, forming an array-like structure that orchestrates the flow of program execution and manages the sequence of function invocations.

package.title: Package
package.description: A package organizes modules into namespaces, providing a unique namespace for each type it contains.

module.title: Module
module.description: A module or class that encloses functions/methods and other code.

function.title: Function
function.description: A block of code designed to perform a particular task.

parameters.title: Parameters
parameters.description: Optional arguments that are passed to the module or function.

line.title: Line
line.description: The line number the code that is called resides on.

column.title: Column
column.description: The column the code that is called resides.

fullFilename.title: Full Filename
fullFilename.description: The full path and filename of the module.

copyright.title: Copyright Evidence
copyright.description: Copyright evidence captures intellectual property assertions, providing evidence of possible ownership and legal protection.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the composition elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

aggregate.title: Aggregate
aggregate.description: Specifies an aggregate type that describe how complete a relationship is.

assemblies.title: BOM references
assemblies.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services being described. Assemblies refer to nested relationships whereby a constituent part may include other constituent parts. References do not cascade to child parts. References are explicit for the specified constituent part only.

dependencies.title: BOM references
dependencies.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the components or services being described. Dependencies refer to a relationship whereby an independent constituent part requires another independent constituent part. References do not cascade to transitive dependencies. References are explicit for the specified dependency only.

vulnerabilities.title: BOM references
vulnerabilities.description: The bom-ref identifiers of the vulnerabilities being described.

meta:enum.complete: The relationship is complete. No further relationships including constituent components, services, or dependencies are known to exist.
meta:enum.incomplete: The relationship is incomplete. Additional relationships exist and may include constituent components, services, or dependencies.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_proprietary_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are proprietary.
meta:enum.incomplete_first_party_opensource_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for first-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are opensource.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_proprietary_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are proprietary.
meta:enum.incomplete_third_party_opensource_only: The relationship is incomplete. Only relationships for third-party components, services, or their dependencies are represented, limited specifically to those that are opensource.
meta:enum.unknown: The relationship may be complete or incomplete. This usually signifies a 'best-effort' to obtain constituent components, services, or dependencies but the completeness is inconclusive.
meta:enum.not_specified: The relationship completeness is not specified.

property.title: Lightweight name-value pair
property.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the property. Duplicate names are allowed, each potentially having a different value.

localeType.title: Locale
localeType.description: Defines a syntax for representing two character language code (ISO-639) followed by an optional two character country code. The language code MUST be lower case. If the country code is specified, the country code MUST be upper case. The language code and country code MUST be separated by a minus sign. Examples: en, en-US, fr, fr-CA

releaseType.description:
The software versioning type. It is RECOMMENDED that the release type use one of 'major', 'minor', 'patch', 'pre-release', or 'internal'. Representing all possible software release types is not practical, so standardizing on the recommended values, whenever possible, is strongly encouraged.

* __major__ = A major release may contain significant changes or may introduce breaking changes.
* __minor__ = A minor release, also known as an update, may contain a smaller number of changes than major releases.
* __patch__ = Patch releases are typically unplanned and may resolve defects or important security issues.
* __pre-release__ = A pre-release may include alpha, beta, or release candidates and typically have limited support. They provide the ability to preview a release prior to its general availability.
* __internal__ = Internal releases are not for public consumption and are intended to be used exclusively by the project or manufacturer that produced it.

note.title: Note
note.description: A note containing the locale and content.

locale.title: Locale
locale.description: The ISO-639 (or higher) language code and optional ISO-3166 (or higher) country code. Examples include: "en", "en-US", "fr" and "fr-CA"

text.title: Release note content
text.description: Specifies the full content of the release note.

type.title: Type
type.description: The software versioning type the release note describes.

featuredImage.title: Featured image
featuredImage.description: The URL to an image that may be prominently displayed with the release note.

socialImage.title: Social image
socialImage.description: The URL to an image that may be used in messaging on social media platforms.

description.title: Description
description.description: A short description of the release.

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the release note was created.

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: One or more alternate names the release may be referred to. This may include unofficial terms used by development and marketing teams (e.g. code names).

resolves.title: Resolves
resolves.description: A collection of issues that have been resolved.

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: Zero or more release notes containing the locale and content. Multiple note objects may be specified to support release notes in a wide variety of languages.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

advisory.title: Advisory
advisory.description: Title and location where advisory information can be obtained. An advisory is a notification of a threat to a component, service, or system.

title.title: Title
title.description: An optional name of the advisory.

url.title: URL
url.description: Location where the advisory can be obtained.

cwe.title: CWE
cwe.description: Integer representation of a Common Weaknesses Enumerations (CWE). For example 399 (of https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/399.html)

severity.title: Severity
severity.description: Textual representation of the severity of the vulnerability adopted by the analysis method. If the analysis method uses values other than what is provided, the user is expected to translate appropriately.

scoreMethod.title: Method
scoreMethod.description: Specifies the severity or risk scoring methodology or standard used.

meta:enum.other: Another severity or risk scoring methodology

impactAnalysisState.title: Impact Analysis State
impactAnalysisState.description: Declares the current state of an occurrence of a vulnerability, after automated or manual analysis.

meta:enum.resolved_with_pedigree: The vulnerability has been remediated and evidence of the changes are provided in the affected components pedigree containing verifiable commit history and/or diff(s).
meta:enum.exploitable: The vulnerability may be directly or indirectly exploitable.
meta:enum.false_positive: The vulnerability is not specific to the component or service and was falsely identified or associated.
meta:enum.not_affected: The component or service is not affected by the vulnerability. Justification should be specified for all not_affected cases.

impactAnalysisJustification.title: Impact Analysis Justification
impactAnalysisJustification.description: The rationale of why the impact analysis state was asserted.

meta:enum.code_not_present: The code has been removed or tree-shaked.
meta:enum.code_not_reachable: The vulnerable code is not invoked at runtime.
meta:enum.requires_configuration: Exploitability requires a configurable option to be set/unset.
meta:enum.requires_dependency: Exploitability requires a dependency that is not present.
meta:enum.requires_environment: Exploitability requires a certain environment which is not present.
meta:enum.protected_by_compiler: Exploitability requires a compiler flag to be set/unset.
meta:enum.protected_at_perimeter: Attacks are blocked at physical, logical, or network perimeter.
meta:enum.protected_by_mitigating_control: Preventative measures have been implemented that reduce the likelihood and/or impact of the vulnerability.

rating.title: Rating
rating.description: Defines the severity or risk ratings of a vulnerability.

source.description: The source that calculated the severity or risk rating of the vulnerability.

score.title: Score
score.description: The numerical score of the rating.

severity.description: Textual representation of the severity that corresponds to the numerical score of the rating.

vector.title: Vector
vector.description: Textual representation of the metric values used to score the vulnerability

justification.title: Justification
justification.description: An optional reason for rating the vulnerability as it was

vulnerabilitySource.title: Source
vulnerabilitySource.description: The source of vulnerability information. This is often the organization that published the vulnerability.

url.title: URL
url.description: The url of the vulnerability documentation as provided by the source.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name of the source.

vulnerability.title: Vulnerability
vulnerability.description: Defines a weakness in a component or service that could be exploited or triggered by a threat source.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the vulnerability elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

id.title: ID
id.description: The identifier that uniquely identifies the vulnerability.

source.description: The source that published the vulnerability.

references.title: References
references.description: Zero or more pointers to vulnerabilities that are the equivalent of the vulnerability specified. Often times, the same vulnerability may exist in multiple sources of vulnerability intelligence, but have different identifiers. References provide a way to correlate vulnerabilities across multiple sources of vulnerability intelligence.

id.title: ID
id.description: An identifier that uniquely identifies the vulnerability.

source.description: The source that published the vulnerability.

cwes.title: CWEs
cwes.description: List of Common Weaknesses Enumerations (CWEs) codes that describes this vulnerability.

description.title: Description
description.description: A description of the vulnerability as provided by the source.

detail.title: Details
detail.description: If available, an in-depth description of the vulnerability as provided by the source organization. Details often include information useful in understanding root cause.

recommendation.title: Recommendation
recommendation.description: Recommendations of how the vulnerability can be remediated or mitigated.

workaround.title: Workarounds
workaround.description: A bypass, usually temporary, of the vulnerability that reduces its likelihood and/or impact. Workarounds often involve changes to configuration or deployments.

proofOfConcept.title: Proof of Concept
proofOfConcept.description: Evidence used to reproduce the vulnerability.

reproductionSteps.title: Steps to Reproduce
reproductionSteps.description: Precise steps to reproduce the vulnerability.

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: A description of the environment in which reproduction was possible.

supportingMaterial.title: Supporting Material
supportingMaterial.description: Supporting material that helps in reproducing or understanding how reproduction is possible. This may include screenshots, payloads, and PoC exploit code.

advisories.title: Advisories
advisories.description: Published advisories of the vulnerability if provided.

created.title: Created
created.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the vulnerability record was created in the vulnerability database.

published.title: Published
published.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the vulnerability record was first published.

updated.title: Updated
updated.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the vulnerability record was last updated.

rejected.title: Rejected
rejected.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the vulnerability record was rejected (if applicable).

credits.title: Credits
credits.description: Individuals or organizations credited with the discovery of the vulnerability.

organizations.title: Organizations
organizations.description: The organizations credited with vulnerability discovery.

individuals.title: Individuals
individuals.description: The individuals, not associated with organizations, that are credited with vulnerability discovery.

tools.title: Tools
tools.description: The tool(s) used to identify, confirm, or score the vulnerability.

oneOf.title: Tools
oneOf.description: The tool(s) used to identify, confirm, or score the vulnerability.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of software and hardware components used as tools.

services.title: Services
services.description: A list of services used as tools. This may include microservices, function-as-a-service, and other types of network or intra-process services.

oneOf.title: Tools (legacy)
oneOf.description: [Deprecated] The tool(s) used to identify, confirm, or score the vulnerability.

analysis.title: Impact Analysis
analysis.description: An assessment of the impact and exploitability of the vulnerability.

response.title: Response
response.description: A response to the vulnerability by the manufacturer, supplier, or project responsible for the affected component or service. More than one response is allowed. Responses are strongly encouraged for vulnerabilities where the analysis state is exploitable.

meta:enum.update: Update to a different revision or release
meta:enum.rollback: Revert to a previous revision or release

detail.title: Detail
detail.description: Detailed description of the impact including methods used during assessment. If a vulnerability is not exploitable, this field should include specific details on why the component or service is not impacted by this vulnerability.

firstIssued.title: First Issued
firstIssued.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the analysis was first issued.

lastUpdated.title: Last Updated
lastUpdated.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the analysis was last updated.

ref.title: Reference
ref.description: References a component or service by the objects bom-ref

versions.title: Versions
versions.description: Zero or more individual versions or range of versions.

version.title: Version
version.description: A single version of a component or service.

range.title: Version Range
range.description: A version range specified in Package URL Version Range syntax (vers) which is defined at https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec/VERSION-RANGE-SPEC.rst

status.title: Status
status.description: The vulnerability status for the version or range of versions.

affects.title: Affects
affects.description: The components or services that are affected by the vulnerability.

properties.title: Properties
properties.description: Provides the ability to document properties in a name-value store. This provides flexibility to include data not officially supported in the standard without having to use additional namespaces or create extensions. Unlike key-value stores, properties support duplicate names, each potentially having different values. Property names of interest to the general public are encouraged to be registered in the [CycloneDX Property Taxonomy](https://github.com/CycloneDX/cyclonedx-property-taxonomy). Formal registration is OPTIONAL.

affectedStatus.description: The vulnerability status of a given version or range of versions of a product. The statuses 'affected' and 'unaffected' indicate that the version is affected or unaffected by the vulnerability. The status 'unknown' indicates that it is unknown or unspecified whether the given version is affected. There can be many reasons for an 'unknown' status, including that an investigation has not been undertaken or that a vendor has not disclosed the status.

meta:enum.affected: The version is affected by the vulnerability.
meta:enum.unaffected: The version is not affected by the vulnerability.
meta:enum.unknown: It is unknown (or unspecified) whether the given version is affected.

version.description: A single disjunctive version identifier, for a component or service.

versionRange.description: A version range specified in Package URL Version Range syntax (vers) which is defined at https://github.com/package-url/purl-spec/VERSION-RANGE-SPEC.rst

annotations.title: Annotations
annotations.description: A comment, note, explanation, or similar textual content which provides additional context to the object(s) being annotated.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the annotation elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

subjects.title: Subjects
subjects.description: The object in the BOM identified by its bom-ref. This is often a component or service, but may be any object type supporting bom-refs.

annotator.title: Annotator
annotator.description: The organization, person, component, or service which created the textual content of the annotation.

organization.description: The organization that created the annotation

individual.description: The person that created the annotation

component.description: The tool or component that created the annotation

service.description: The service that created the annotation

timestamp.title: Timestamp
timestamp.description: The date and time (timestamp) when the annotation was created.

text.title: Text
text.description: The textual content of the annotation.

modelCard.$comment: Model card support in CycloneDX is derived from TensorFlow Model Card Toolkit released under the Apache 2.0 license and available from https://github.com/tensorflow/model-card-toolkit/blob/main/model_card_toolkit/schema/v0.0.2/model_card.schema.json. In addition, CycloneDX model card support includes portions of VerifyML, also released under the Apache 2.0 license and available from https://github.com/cylynx/verifyml/blob/main/verifyml/model_card_toolkit/schema/v0.0.4/model_card.schema.json.
modelCard.title: Model Card
modelCard.description: A model card describes the intended uses of a machine learning model and potential limitations, including biases and ethical considerations. Model cards typically contain the training parameters, which datasets were used to train the model, performance metrics, and other relevant data useful for ML transparency. This object SHOULD be specified for any component of type `machine-learning-model` and MUST NOT be specified for other component types.

bom-ref.title: BOM Reference
bom-ref.description:
An optional identifier which can be used to reference the model card elsewhere in the BOM. Every bom-ref MUST be unique within the BOM.
Value SHOULD not start with the BOM-Link intro 'urn:cdx:' to avoid conflicts with BOM-Links.

modelParameters.title: Model Parameters
modelParameters.description: Hyper-parameters for construction of the model.

approach.title: Approach
approach.description: The overall approach to learning used by the model for problem solving.

type.title: Learning Type
type.description: Learning types describing the learning problem or hybrid learning problem.

meta:enum.supervised: Supervised machine learning involves training an algorithm on labeled data to predict or classify new data based on the patterns learned from the labeled examples.
